Graphical abstract Currently, highly efficient catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol is attracting intensive attention. However, constructing high-performance catalysts for methanol synthesis that can be operated under mild reaction conditions is a challenging task. In this work, a series of indium-doped ZrO2 supported copper-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation were constructed via one-pot hydrogen bubble-assisted approach. It was manifested that the in situ introduction of indium facilitated the generation of interfacial defects in the form of Zr-Vo-In3+ structure (Vo: oxygen vacancy) and interfacial Cu+ sites, as well as surface basic sites originating from In-O pairs, and the catalytic performance of as-constructed In-doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts could be efficiently promoted by tuning the indium content. Specifically, the Cu-based catalyst bearing the indium content of 4.0 wt% afforded the quite high space-time yield of methanol (0.398 gMeOH h−1·gcat −1) at 270 °C, while the one with the indium content of 8.0 wt% yielded an increased methanol selectivity by 1.8 times at 250 °C, compared with undoped one. Combining the structural characterizations with catalytic results, it was found that surface medium-strength and strong basic sites together with the contribution from interfacial defective oxygen vacancies and Cu+ sites played key promotional roles on the synthesis of methanol. This finding enables us to design new high-performance Cu-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation by finely turning their surface-interface structures. Keywords In situ construction Indium Interfacial structure CO2 hydrogenation Methanol synthesis 1 Introduction Currently, various technologies for capturing and transforming CO2 greenhouse gas into important chemicals and fuels are being paid intensive attention because it can not only alleviate caused global warming issue but also mitigate the dependence on non-renewable fossil fuels [1–3]. Considering that green water electrolysis with renewable energy can allow hydrogen to be produced at a large scale [4–6], CO2 hydrogenation to produce oxygenates and hydrocarbons is a very attractive approach. Especially, as methanol can be utilized to manufacture olefins, aromatics, and gasolines, the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation into methanol has become a potentially strategic important process [7–9]. In this regard, although Cu/ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst was widely employed in the methanol production based on syngas in practical industrial process, harsh reaction conditions and poor catalyst performance make it essential to develop new high-performance catalyst materials for CO2 hydrogenation under mild reaction conditions [10–12]. Although supported Pd catalysts always exhibit good activity for CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol [13–15], the utilization of noble metal catalysts is still not as common as copper-based catalysts, due to their high cost and the easy sintering during the reaction. As for Cu-based catalysts, Cu nanoparticles (NPs) usually are loaded on various metal oxides such as alumina [10,16], SiO2 [17,18], ZrO2 [19,20], ZnO [21,22], and TiO2 [23]. Among these supports, ZrO2 is an excellent support, thanks to its weak hydrophilicity and the promotional effect on the metal dispersion. Specifically, the effect of the interface sites between copper species and ZrO2 on the CO2 hydrogenation has also been investigated [24,25]. It was found that the incorporation of other additives, such as CeO2 and Ga2O3, played a positive effect on the enhancement of catalytic performance [26–28]. Recently, the density functional theory (DFT) studies on the activation of CO2 revealed that the formation of HCOO intermediate species at oxygen vacancies on the In2O3 surface was both thermodynamically and kinetically favorable during methanol synthesis [29,30]. Although good methanol selectivities over the In2O3 can be achieved under high reaction pressures (> 4.0 Mpa) at the expense of sacrificing the CO2 conversions [31–34], high methanol yields are still hardly obtained due to the limited H2-splitting ability of In2O3. Along this line, a few researches have been focused on the modification of indium oxide catalysts to improve the production of methanol, such as atomic-scale dispersion of palladium on indium oxide matrix [35]. Therefore, more highly efficient In-containing catalysts are also required to be further designed. On the other side, as we know, the special surface structure and interfacial sites of supported catalysts can provide key functionalities in complex catalytic reactions. Several works have been reported to explore the roles of surface structures and interfacial sites in the CO2 hydrogenations [36–39]. For instance, it was reported that the surface structure of bimetallic Pd-Cu alloy could stabilize the reaction intermediates and transition states in the CO2 hydrogenation, thus changing the reaction paths and regulating the methanol selectivity [36]. Based on the DFT calculations and kinetic simulations, it was inferred that CO2 absorption and reaction mainly occurred at Cu-ZrO2 interfaces [37]. It was proposed that regulating (Zr)2–O–Cu interface linkage and controlling the O-affinity of the oxide cationic sites might be pivotal to methanol synthesis. Additionally, it was found that interfacial sites between Cu and amorphous ZrO2 were specific active sites for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [25]. Therefore, modulating surface structure and interfacial sites of Cu-based catalysts is of great significance to govern their catalytic performance in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Inspired by previous pioneering studies, in this work, we constructed a series of indium-doped ZrO2 supported copper catalysts (Cu/In-ZrO2) via our developed one-pot hydrogen bubble-assisted approach and employed for CO2 hydrogenation. It was demonstrated that the in situ introduction of indium caused the structural distortion of ZrO2 lattice, thus leading to the formation of more interfacial defects (e.g. oxygen vacancies). Remarkably, as-constructed Cu/In-ZrO2 catalyst bearing the indium content of 4.0 wt.% afforded the highest space-time yield of methanol of 0.398 gMeOH h−1·gcat −1 at 270 °C, while the one with the indium content of 8.0 wt.% yielded an increased methanol selectivity by 1.8 times under mild reaction conditions (i.e. 250 °C, 3.0 MPa), compared with the undoped one. The effects of surface-interface structures on the electronic states of active metal species, surface acid-base sites, and catalytic performance of the prepared Cu/ZrO2 and Cu/In-ZrO2 catalyst were investigated. It was concluded that the effects of surface basic sites together with the contribution from both interfacial defects and Cu+ sites could account for the high catalytic efficiency of the as-constructed supported copper catalysts. The present findings create an excellent approach to tune the surface-interface structures of supported copper catalysts for highly efficient synthesis of methanol. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Sample preparation Indium-doped ZrO2 supported copper catalysts were prepared via one-pot hydrogen bubble-assisted approach developed by our group [40,41]. In a typical synthesis of Cu-based sample with the loading of Cu of 25 % and the Cu:In molar ratio of 54.2 : 4.0, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (5 × 10−3 mol), In(NO3)3 (3.4 × 10-4 mol), and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (3.8 × 10-3 mol) were dissolved into deionized water (40 mL) to form A solution, while NaBH4 with a 1:10 [Cu + In + Zr]/[NaBH4] molar ratio was added into deionized water (40 mL) to form B solution. Afterwards, above two solutions were concurrently put into a micro-liquid-film reactor at a flow rate of 5 mL/s at a 4000-rpm rotor speed and held for 3 min at room temperature and atmospheric pressure, which involved a hydrogen bubble-assisted process [40]. Subsequently, the formed suspension was aged at 423 K for one day. Similar procedure was adopted for preparation of all Cu-based samples, in which the Cu:In molar ratio was set at 54.2 : x (x = 0, 1, 4, 8). Then, under air atmosphere, the obtained precipitate was calcined at 723 K and held for 4 h to gain CuO/ZrO2 and CuO/In-ZrO2 precursors. Finally, CuO/ZrO2 and CuO/In-ZrO2 were reduced at 573 K in a flow of 10 vol% H2/N2 for 2 h to obtain Cu/ZrO2 and Cu/In-ZrO2-x with copper and indium loading amounts of about 30 wt % and x wt%, respectively. For comparison, commercial ZrO2 supported Cu-based reference catalyst (im-Cu/In-ZrO2-4) was synthesized by the impregnation method. Two cop-Cu/In-ZrO2-4 and benchmark Cu/ZnO-Al2O3 (Cu:Al:Zn molar ratio: 6:1:3) reference catalysts were synthesized by the conventional coprecipitation. All reference samples were calcined and reduced under the same conditions as those for Cu/In-ZrO2-x samples. 2.2 Sample characterization Bruker D8 diffractometer with Cu Kα source was applied to record X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM-energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (HAADF-STEM-EDX) were performed using JEOL 2010 F and JEOL JEM-2100 electron microscope, respectively. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) experiments were performed on Bruker EMX-500 spectrometer with a microwave frequency of 9.43 GHz and the spectra were recorded at 100 K. The g factor (or g value) can be calculated by the Eq. (1): (1) g = hν/βH where h is the Planck constant, ν is the frequency of electromagnetic wave, β is the Bohr magneton, and H is the magnetic field [42]. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) was collected from Shimadzu Axis Supra X-ray photoelectron spectrometer equipped with Al Kα radiation. X-ray induced Auger spectra (XAES) of copper species were obtained from PHI Quantera SXM instrument. Before the XPS experiments, the calcined catalyst precursor was reduced at 573 K for 2 h with 10 % H2/N2 (100 mL min−1) in the reaction chamber. Afterwards, the reaction chamber was sealed and placed to a vacuum glove box. Subsequently, the catalyst was transferred into the XPS transfer chamber in a vacuum glove box. Finally, the fresh reduced catalyst was transferred to the XPS measurement chamber (10−9 Pa) via the transfer chamber (10−6 Pa) for XPS analysis. The metal content was determined by Shimadzu ICPMS-2030 inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis. Photoluminescence (PL) emission experiments were conducted using Shimadzu RF-6000 fluorescence spectrophotometer with excitation wavelength 255 nm. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted on Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), CO2-TPD, and hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were conducted on Mircomeritics Autochem II chemical adsorption instrument. For H2-TPR, the sample (100 mg) was placed in a quartz U-tube reactor and degassed under Ar flow at 200 °C for 1 h. TPR analysis was carried out in a flow of 10 % H2/Ar (40 mL min−1) with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from 50 to 800 °C. For CO2-TPD, the sample (100 mg) was reduced in a flow of 10 % H2/Ar atmosphere at 300 °C for 2 h with a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1.Then the sample was degassed at 200 °C for 1 h under He flow (40 mL/min) and followed by treatment with a CO2 flow (50 mL/min) for 1 h at 50 °C. Afterwards, the physisorbed CO2 was flushed off under He flow (40 mL/min) at 50 °C for 1 h. Chemisorbed CO2 was desorbed in a flow of Ar by heating the temperature up to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. NH3-TPD experiments were determined under the similar conditions. N2O titration was used to determine copper surface areas (SCu) of samples, considering that surface density of spherical metal particles is 1.47 × 1019 atoms/m2. In situ infrared spectroscopy of pyridine adsorbed (Py-IR) on samples was determined by using a Thermo Nicolet 380 spectrometer. The calcined sample (50 mg) was pressed into a self-supporting wafer, followed by reduction in 10 % H2/Ar atmosphere at 300 °C for 2 h in an IR cell with CaF2 windows. The wafer was evacuated at 200 °C under argon ﬂow and cooled down to room temperature before pyridine was introduced and balanced for 1 h. Finally, physisorbed pyridine was removed by evacuation and the Py-IR spectra were recorded. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) for CO2 hydrogenation were collected by Bruker Tensor II spectrometer with an MCT detector. The calcined samples (∼60 mg) were placed in an in situ DRIFTS cell fitted with BaF2 windows and flushed with 10 % H2/Ar (40 mL/ min) for 10 min and then reduced for 2 h at 573 K. Afterwards, the gas flow was switched to CO2 (50 mL/min) at 298 K for 30 min. Finally, a mixture of CO2/H2 (1:3) was passed through reduced samples and then the in situ DRIFTS spectra were collected at different temperatures. 2.3 Catalytic CO2 hydrogenation The CO2 hydrogenations were carried out on a continuous fixed-bed stainless steel reactor (the tube length and the internal diameter were 400 and 8 mm, respectively). The reaction tube was loaded with 0.2 g catalyst precursor pellets (40–60 mesh) mixed with an equal amount of quartz sand. Prior to CO2 hydrogenation, the precursor was in situ reduced at 573 K for 2 h with 10 % H2/N2 flow. Furthermore, the catalytic performance was measured under a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 18000 mL⋅ g−1⋅ h−1 at 493–543 K and 3.0 MPa. The mixture gas (CO2: H2: Ar = 24:72:4, v/v) with a 60 mL/min flow rate was fed. The reaction stream was online analyzed by Agilent 7890B gas chromatography using a two-column system (SE-54 column and TDX-01 column) connected to thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and flame ionized detector (FID), respectively. Reaction results were collected after 2 h at steady state conditions. The CO2 conversions (XCO2, %) were calculated by both internal standard method and mass-balanced method based on Eqs. (2) and (3). Meanwhile, the methanol selectivity (SelMeOH, %), methanol space-time yield (STY, gMeOH⋅ gcat −1⋅ h−1), turnover frequency for CO2 conversion (TOFCO2), and turnover frequency for methanol formation (TOFMeOH) were calculated based on Eqs. (4)–(7). Each catalytic testing was repeated for three times. In each case, the CO2 conversion obtained by internal standard method was almost equal to the value calculated by mass-balanced method, while the errors of conversion, selectivity and space-time yield values were less than about 0.5 %, 1.0 %, and 0.03 gMeOH⋅gcat −1⋅ h−1, respectively. Moreover, in all cases, the carbon balances were more than 99.0 %. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structural characterizations Fig. 1 A shows XRD patterns of calcined Cu-based samples. In all cases, the diffractions observed at 2θ angles of 30.2°, 35.4°, 50.5° and 60.1° correspond to (011), (110), (020), and (121) crystal faces of tetragonal ZrO2 phase (JCPDS 50-1089), respectively, which are reduced remarkably with the indium content. Moreover, the (111) diffraction for CuO phase appearing at 2θ of 38.4° is attenuated with the indium content. Meanwhile, in the cases of higher indium contents, several weak diffractions related to InOOH phase (JCPDS No. 17-0549) can be detected. It illustrates that the radius and valence effects generated by the in situ introduction of indium can result in the decreasing size of CuO particles and the structural distortion of t-ZrO2 lattice. Fig. 1B displays XRD patterns of different supported copper samples. The diffraction peak around 43.4° for all patterns could be well indexed as the (111) crystal plane for metallic copper phase. The average crystalline size of metallic copper particles calculated based on the Scherrer equation increase gradually from 21 to 30 nm with the indium content increasing from 0 to 8.0 wt% (Table 1 ). However, no crystalline In2O3 phase is observed, probably owing to the small size of In-containing oxide particles and low content of indium [43], as well as the successful incorporation of indium into the t-ZrO2 structure. TEM images of Cu-based samples (Fig. 2 a–d) describe that large quantities of dark small copper particles are distributed over the support surface, and that the agglomeration of NPs is aggravated gradually with the indium content. Apparently, compared with those determined through XRD line broadening, the average sizes of Cu particles obtained from TEM observation are much smaller (Table 1), due to the fact that XRD mainly reﬂects the intense diffractions originating from large-sized particles, thus overshadowing the contribution of those small-sized particles [44]. A representative HRTEM image of Cu/In-ZrO2-4 (Fig. 2e) visualizes the (111), (222), and (010) crystal planes of metallic Cu, In2O3, and ZrO2 phases [45], respectively, along with the d-spacings of about 2.09 Å, 2.92 Å, and 2.95 Å and the intimate interfaces between copper particles and t-ZrO2 crystals and between In2O3 and t-ZrO2 crystals. Further, HAADF–STEM images (Fig. 2f–i) disclose the similar spatial distribution of indium, copper, zirconium, and oxygen within a single particle. Along a single particle, the Cu, In and Zr scan spectra (Fig. 2j) depict the same Gaussian distributions of three elements, reflecting the similarly homogeneous distributions of these elements and close contact between them. As summarized in Table 1, the indium contents determined by the ICP-AES analysis are in good concurrence with the theoretical values, and the specific surface area of Cu/ZrO2 sample reaches as high as 163 m2/g. However, surface areas of Cu/In-ZrO2 samples gradually decrease with the indium content, mainly due to the slightly enhanced agglomeration of particles. Furthermore, it is seen that the copper surface areas of Cu/In-ZrO2 samples are smaller than that of Cu/ZrO2 sample (23.4 m2⋅ g−1), well consistent with the above XRD results. As shown in Fig. 3 , the H2-TPR curves of different calcined Cu-based catalyst precursors can be divided into three regions, due to the reduction of highly dispersive isolated CuO particles (100−190℃), CuO in bulk (190–270 ℃), and In2O3 at high temperatures (>600 °C) [46]. Noticeably, the low-temperature reduction shifts from 170 to 161 °C with the introduction of indium. Meanwhile, in the case of CuO/In-ZrO2-8 sample, in addition to the reduction peak associated with CuO in bulk at 234 °C, a small shoulder appears at a higher temperature of about 248 °C, which mainly originates from the reduction of large-sized bulk CuO particles, probably due to the introduction of larger amounts of indium into Cu-based catalyst precursor, thus causing the formation of larger CuO particles in the calcined precursor. It manifests that the introduction of appropriate amounts of indium can ameliorate the reducibility of Cu species. However, the improved reducibility of Cu species may lead to the formation of larger Cu nanoparticles, thereby reducing the exposure of active metallic Cu sites in the case of CuO/In-ZrO2-8 (Table 1), which is unfavorable to the dissociation of H2 during the CO2 hydrogenation. 3.2 Surface-interface properties of samples The surface electronic structures of Cu, In, and O species for Cu-based samples were investigated by XPS (Fig. 4 ). As shown in Fig. 4A, in all cases, two peaks at approximately 932.8 and 952.7 eV are assigned to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 core levels, respectively, without the presence of a shake-up satellite peak in the range of 940−945 eV, verifying the reduction of Cu2+ species [47]. Further, Cu LMM XAES spectra (Fig. 4B) reveal the coexistence of surface Cu° and Cu+ species [48]. As summarized in Table 1, surface Cu+/(Cu++ Cu°) ratio first increases with the indium content and then decreases. Specifically, Cu/In-ZrO2-4 sample possesses a maxima surface fraction of Cu+ species (0.59), probably forming more stable interfacial Cu+ sites in the form of Zr-O-Cu+-like or In-O-Cu+-like structure at the interface between ZrO2 or In2O3 and copper particles [40]. Usually, the smaller the metal particle size, the lower the contact area between metal particles and the support. Therefore, despite the decreased copper surface area with the increasing In content in the cases of lower In doping amounts (≤ 4.0 wt.%), the number of Cu+ atoms in contact with the In-ZrO2 support at the perimeter of the Cu NPs, as well as Cu+/(Cu++ Cu°) ratio, can increase with the increase in the Cu particle size, due to the strong metal-support interactions. For Cu/In-ZrO2-8, however, surface Cu+/(Cu++Cu°) ratio inversely decreases, indicative of the weakening of the metal-support interactions. Previously, it was reported that Cu+ species as electrophilic sites could polarize the carbonyl group via the electron lone pair in oxygen atom, thereby promoting the carbonyl hydrogenation [49]. As shown in Fig. 4C, two In 3d5/2 and In 3d3/2 signals (444.7 and 452.3 eV) confirm the presence of In3+ species [46]. The fine O1 s spectra for Cu-based samples show two fitted peaks at 530.7 and 532.0 eV (Fig. 4D), which are corelated with the lattice oxygen species (OI) and adsorbed oxygen species on oxygen vacancies and hydroxyl groups (OII) [50], respectively. The OII/OI intensity ratio representing the relative number of defects is significantly increased with the indium content (Table 1), suggesting that the introduction of indium can promote the generation of more oxygen vacancies. Fig. 5 A shows the PL spectra of reduced copper catalysts at an excitation wavelength of 255 nm. Noticeably, a broad peak originating from the exciton recombination at oxygen vacancies appears at approximately 361 nm [51,52]. It is noteworthy that the emission peak of Cu/In-ZrO2-8 sample is much stronger than that of other samples, reflecting the formation of a larger amount of oxygen vacancies. It is inferred that the introduction of indium can cause the structural distortion of ZrO2 lattice. To further confirm defective structure, EPR spectra of Cu-based samples were collected (Fig. 5B). An EPR peak with a g factor of 2.046 is attributed to a single electron trapped at the oxygen vacancy having +1 charge state with the formation of F-centers [52,53]. With the introduction of indium, the significantly enhanced intensity of EPR signal for Cu-based samples reflects the generation of more oxygen vacancies. Moreover, the quantity of oxygen vacancies could be counted to clarify the difference in samples (Fig. 5C). It demonstrates that the quantity of oxygen vacancies is increased gradually with the indium content, well consistent with the above XPS and PL results. Previously, it was reported that the tensile strain formed via the doping of zirconia with other elements could lower the formation energy of oxygen vacancy [54]. In our case, it is inferred that the in situ introduction of indium may cause the distortion of the t-ZrO2 lattice and thus the generation of oxygen vacancy (Vo) in the form of interfacial Zr4+-Vo-In3+ -like structure. Fig. 6 A shows in situ IR spectra of pyridine adsorption on different copper-based samples. Several absorption bands in the range of 1425–1650 cm−1 are assigned to H-bonding (HB) adsorbed pyridine (1600 cm−1), adsorbed pyridine on Lewis acidic (LA) sites (1448 and 1613 cm−1), and adsorbed pyridine Brønsted/Lewis acidic (LA + BA) sites (1495 cm−1) [55,56]. Noticeably, all the bands are reduced with the introduction of indium, demonstrating the decreased surface acidity. Furthermore, NH3-TPD experiments was conducted to determine the amount of surface acidic sites. As shown in Fig. 6B, in the NH3-TPD profiles of samples, a broad desorption is obviously deconvoluted into four or five subpeaks, which are owing to the desorption of NH3 on weak acidic sites (50–250 °C), medium-strength acidic sites (250−500 °C), and strong acidic sites (above 500 °C) [57]. It is found that the incorporation of indium into the structure of ZrO2 can contribute to the decrement in the density of total acidic sites and medium-strength acidic sites (Table 1). On the other side, surface basicity was identified by CO2-TPD experiments. In the CO2-TPD profiles (Fig. 6C), there are three deconvoluted regions: weak basic (WB) sites related to OH- groups (50−200 °C), medium-strength basic (MB) sites from metal–oxygen pairs (e.g. In–O and Zr–O pairs) (200–450 °C), and strong basic (SB) sites associated with low-coordination O2- species (450−750 °C) [58,59]. As listed in Table 1, the density of basic sites on samples, as well as the density of medium-strength and strong basic sites, presents an increasing trend with the indium content, mainly due to the presence of more In-O pairs originating from In2O3 component. As for CO2 hydrogenation, it is believed that surface basic sites can facilitate the adsorption of CO2, and surface acidic sites can improve the dispersion of active metal sites [60]. Therefore, it is crucial to modify surface acidity and basicity of supported copper samples to govern the CO2 conversion. 3.3 Catalytic performances of Cu-based catalysts Over different supported copper catalysts, the CO2 hydrogenation was conducted at different temperatures. As displayed in Fig. 7 A, the methanol selectivity increases with the indium content, reflecting the promotional effect of the doping of indium on the formation of methanol. Specifically, the methanol selectivity over the Cu/In-ZrO2-8 reaches 68 % at 523 K, which is 1.8 times higher than that over the In-free copper catalyst (37 %). As we know, the methanol selectivity always drops with the elevated reaction temperatures, because the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction producing CO is an endothermic process. As shown in Fig. 7B, the CO2 conversion presents an increasing trend with the reaction temperature in each case. However, the CO2 conversion decreases gradually with the indium content, because of the decrease in the amount of active metallic sites. As shown in Fig. 7C, notably, the space-time-yield (STY) of methanol over the Cu/In-ZrO2-4 reaches the highest value (0.398 gMeOH h−1·gcat −1) at 543 K. In the case of Cu/In-ZrO2-4, the appropriate amount of In doping not only gives rise to the high CO2 conversion, but only facilitates the formation of methanol. Interestingly, despite much lower CO2 conversion over the Cu/In-ZrO2-8 than that over the Cu/ZrO2 at 523 K, the STY value of methanol over the Cu/In-ZrO2-8 is almost equal to that over the latter, due to the higher methanol selectivity over the Cu/In-ZrO2-8. In comparison, Cu/In-ZrO2-10 catalyst with a higher indium content of 10 % was further prepared. TEM images reveal serious agglomeration of Cu particles on the surface (Fig. S1), while the N2O titration result indicates a smaller copper surface area (4.2 m2/g) than those of other Cu-based catalysts. Compared with Cu/In-ZrO2-8, Cu/In-ZrO2-10 delivers a much lower CO2 conversion of about 4.4 % with the methanol selectivity of 63 % at 533 K (Fig. S2). Although the increase in the indium content can promote the methanol selectivity to some extent, the methanol yield over the Cu/In-ZrO2-10 is much lower than that over the Cu/In-ZrO2-8, due to the significantly lowered CO2 conversion. Additionally, the loading of indium was controlled at a content of 4% to obtain an indium-zirconia mixed oxide sample (denoted as In-ZrO2-4). As shown in Fig. S3, despite higher methanol selectivities over the In-ZrO2-4 than those over the Cu/In-ZrO2-4 in the reaction temperature range of 493−533 K, the STY values of methanol over the In-ZrO2-4 are much lower than those over the latter, due to the significantly lowered CO2 conversions. The result demonstrates that the H2-splitting ability of In2O3 is much weaker than that of metallic Cu at relatively low reaction temperatures (493−533 K) and low reaction pressures (≤ 3.0 MPa). Therefore, In2O3-based catalysts are more suitable for the CO2 hydrogenation at higher reaction temperatures (>553 K) and reaction pressures (> 4.0 MPa) [31–33,53,61,62]. Moreover, based on the linear change in the Ln (STY value of methanol) with reciprocal of reaction temperatures (Fig. 7D), the apparent activation energy (Ea) for methanol formation obtained from Arrhenius equations is 28.7 for Cu/ZrO2, 26.3 for Cu/In-ZrO2-1, 24.7 for Cu/In-ZrO2-4, and 31.4 kJ mol −1 for Cu/In-ZrO2-8, respectively. As for the RWGS reaction (Fig. S4), however, the Ea value for CO formation increases gradually from 93.0 to 105.6 kJ mol−1 with the increasing indium content. To some extent, the reaction kinetics results demonstrate the positive effect of an appropriate indium doping on the CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol. According to the Le Châtelier’s principle, the reaction pressure plays a vital role in affecting the CO2 hydrogenation. At 523 K and the GHSV value of 18000 mL ⋅ h−1⋅ g-1, the STY value of methanol is sharply increased with the elevated total pressure from 0.1–4.0 MPa (Fig. S5). Besides, the methanol selectivity can be slightly increased with the increasing GHSV value from 6000 to 30000 mL ⋅ h-1⋅ g-1 (Fig. S5), thus inhibiting the RWGS reaction. For comparison, two reference samples, im-Cu/In-ZrO2-4 and cop-Cu/In-ZrO2-4, also were synthesized by the conventional impregnation and coprecipitation. The CO2 conversion and methanol yield over two reference catalysts are inferior than those over the Cu/In-ZrO2-4 (Fig. S6), reflecting that the present Cu-based catalysts are efficient for CO2 hydrogenation. Although the CO2 conversion over the Cu/ZnO-Al2O3 reference catalyst used in practical industry is higher than that over the Cu/In-ZrO2-4 (Fig. S6), the methanol selectivity is much lower than that over the latter. Furthermore, as shown in Table 2 , Cu/In-ZrO2-4 and Cu/In-ZrO2-8 present comparative STY values of methanol to some previously reported Cu-based or containing-In2O3 catalysts under mild reaction conditions [13,23,26,33–35,53,63–66]. The stability of catalysts is vital for the methanol synthesis in the CO2 hydrogenation. Therefore, the long-term stability of Cu/ZrO2 and Cu/In-ZrO2-4 catalysts was compared at 533 K. As presented in Fig. 8 , the CO2 conversion over Cu/ZrO2 and Cu/In-ZrO2-4 is decreased only by about 4.3 % and 1.5 %, respectively, after a time-on-stream of 80 h, Meanwhile, the methanol selectivity over both catalysts remains almost unchanged within 80 h of reaction. In addition, XRD patterns, XPS and TEM images of used catalysts (Figs. S7 and S8, and Table S1) reveal no obvious change in the crystalline structure, chemical states, and copper particle size after reaction, mirroring the good stability of the present Cu-based catalysts. The above results demonstrate that the present Cu/In-ZrO2 catalysts possess great potential in the practical CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol. 3.4 Mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation over Cu-based catalysts As for metal-catalyzed hydrogenation reactions, the exposed metallic copper surface area (SCu) is the predominant factor governing their catalytic performances [67,68]. As shown in Fig. 9 A, the changes in the CO2 conversion with the SCu value reveal that the CO2 conversion in the range of 493–543 K increases with the increasing SCu value, owing to the formation of more active hydrogen species, thus being propitious to the CO2 hydrogenation. The above TPR experiments demonstrate that the introduction of indium can promote the reduction of highly dispersed Cu species, probably resulting in the formation of larger Cu particles. Correspondingly, in the cases of larger Cu particles, the reduction in the metallic copper surface area is not conducive to the generation of active hydrogen species during CO2 hydrogenation, thus decreasing the CO2 conversion. Meanwhile, the changes in the TOFCO2 value with surface Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio at different reaction temperatures are plotted (Fig. 9B). Notably, regardless of different reaction temperatures, the TOFCO2 value linearly raises with surface Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio. Especially, Cu/In-ZrO2-4 having the highest Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio affords a maxima TOFCO2 value. It is well reported that electrophilic Cu+ sites can polarize the carbonyl group [45,49], thereby enhancing the hydrogenation process to some degree. As a result, in the present copper-based, catalyst system both surface metallic copper sites and interfacial Cu+ sites may promote the CO2 hydrogenation. On the other side, as evidenced by structural characterizations, more oxygen vacancies and basic sites can be generated with the in situ introduction of indium. Interestingly, it is noted from Fig. 10 A that in the range of 493–543 K, the methanol selectivity almost increases linearly with either the amount of oxygen vacancies or the density of medium-strength and strong basic sites. Obviously, the highest selectivity of methanol can be gained over the Cu/In-ZrO2-8 with the highest number of oxygen vacancies and the largest density of strong and medium-strength basic sites. Likewise, as shown in Fig. 10B, the TOFMeOH value for the methanol formation is also closely linearly related to either the number of oxygen vacancies or the density of strong and medium-strength basic sites. The above results strongly reflect that both interfacial oxygen vacancies and surface basic sites can play key roles in promoting the methanol formation. To get deep information on the CO2 hydrogenation pathways over the present Cu-based catalysts, in situ DRIFTS spectra were recorded under a flow gas mixture containing of H2 and CO2 (1/3, v/v). For Cu/ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 11 ), the νs(CO3) and νas(CO3) stretching vibrations of bicarbonate (HCO3 −) species appear at 1430 and 1672 cm-1, respectively, gradually decrease in intensity as the elevated desorption temperature, and finally vanish above 100 °C. As the desorption temperature is elevated, two new bands emerges at 1540 and 1625 cm-1, respectively, which are assigned to the νas(CO3) stretching vibrations of surface unidentate carbonate (u-CO3 2-) and bidentate carbonate (b-CO3 2-) species. The vibration bands for formaldehyde (HCOH: 1498 cm-1), formate (HCOO−: 1598 cm-1) and CO (gas state: 2178 cm-1 and linear mode: 2108 cm-1) are observed at 200 ℃ and the CO vibration bands become more intense with the desorption temperature because of the thermodynamic limitation [69,70]. Despite weak intensities of bands, the presence of the bands at 2855, 2930, and 2970 cm-1 further confirm the formation of surface formate species [71]. For Cu/In-ZrO2-4 sample (Fig. 12 ), the vibration bands for formate and formaldehyde species appear at the lower temperature of 100℃, whereas no CO signal is detected even at 200 °C. It illustrates that formate and formaldehyde are more easily formed on Cu/In-ZrO2-4 sample. Furthermore, the band intensity at 2930 cm-1 is much stronger than that on Cu/ZrO2 sample, which is attributable to the contribution of the CH stretching vibration of methoxy group derived from formaldehyde species [69]. According to the above characterization and catalytic results, the improved catalytic performance of In-doped ZrO2 supported copper catalysts may be explained by the following three factors: (i) As for In-doped Cu-based catalysts, CO2-TPD results confirm that the density of surface basic sites increases with the indium content. Correspondingly, different kinds of carbonate species are easily formed at surface basic sites (i.e. In3+–O2− pairs, isolated O2− ions), which is essential for the formation of formate species in the course of CO2 hydrogenation [72]; (ii) XPS, EPR and PL results reveal the formation of oxygen vacancies in the form of interfacial Zr4+-Vo-In3+-like structure. Thus, the carbonate species produced by the action of the basic sites can be adsorbed at oxygen vacancies, thereby facilitating further hydrogenation process; (iii) Cu/In-ZrO2-4 catalyst having the highest surface Cu+/(Cu+ + Cu0) ratio affords the highest methanol yield and TOFCO2 value. Considering that Cu+ sites can promote the carbonyl hydrogenation [49], more interfacial Cu+ sites are conducive to the hydrogenation of intermediates adsorbed at oxygen vacancies. In addition, the CO selectivity over the Cu/In-ZrO2-4 is higher than that over the Cu/In-ZrO2-8, indicating that Cu+ sites can improve the CO formation to some extent. However, In-free Cu/ZrO2 catalyst having the largest density of acidic sites delivers the highest CO2 conversion, because surface acidic sites can not only enhance the metal dispersion and promote the formation of CO [73,74]. As a result, over In-doped ZrO2 supported copper catalysts, a plausible mechanism for CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol is proposed (Scheme 1 ). First, CO2 molecules can interact with surface basic sites to form carbonate species. Subsequently, with the help of dissociative hydrogen species on metallic copper and the polarizing effect of interfacial Cu+ sites on the CO bond of carbonate, carbonate species are hydrogenated to generate formate species adsorbed at oxygen vacancies [75]. Then, through the promotional effect of electrophilic Cu+ sites, formate species can be further hydrogenated in series to generate dioxymethylene, formaldehyde and methoxy intermediate species [76,77], which involves both the formation of the CH bond and the breaking of the CO bond [29]. Finally, the methoxy species are hydrogenated to produce methanol [30,70]. In the present Cu/In-ZrO2 catalyst system, abundant surface medium-strength and strong basic sites together with the contribution from favorable interfacial defects oxygen vacancies and Cu+ sites play key roles in promoting the methanol synthesis. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, In-doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts were successfully in situ constructed via one-pot hydrogen bubble-assisted approach and applied in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Various structural characterizations revealed that the in situ introduction of indium facilitated the formation of surface medium-strength and strong basic sites, interfacial defective sites, and interfacial Cu+ sites. It was found that Cu/In-ZrO2 catalyst bearing an indium loading amount of 8.0 wt% exhibited a high methanol selectivity of 89 % at 493 K and the STY of methanol could reach 0.326 gMeOH ⋅gcat −1⋅ h-1 under relatively mild reaction conditions (i.e. 270 °C, 3.0 MPa). Furthermore, Cu/In-ZrO2 catalyst with the indium content of 4.0 wt% delivered the highest STY value of methanol (0.398 gMeOH ⋅gcat −1⋅ h−1). It was tentatively proposed that abundant surface medium-strength and strong basic sites together with favorable interfacial defective oxygen vacancies and Cu+ sites played key promotional roles on the methanol synthesis. The present findings provide an alternative approach for tuning the catalyst surface-interface structures to construct high-performance supported copper catalysts for efficient CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. coredata.dc:description: Currently, highly efficient catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol is attracting intensive attention. However, constructing high-performance catalysts for methanol synthesis that can be operated under mild reaction conditions is a challenging task. In this work, a series of indium-doped ZrO2 supported copper-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation were constructed via one-pot hydrogen bubble-assisted approach. It was manifested that the in situ introduction of indium facilitated the generation of interfacial defects in the form of Zr-Vo-In3+ structure (Vo: oxygen vacancy) and interfacial Cu+ sites, as well as surface basic sites originating from In-O pairs, and the catalytic performance of as-constructed In-doped Cu/ZrO2 catalysts could be efficiently promoted by tuning the indium content. Specifically, the Cu-based catalyst bearing the indium content of 4.0 wt% afforded the quite high space-time yield of methanol (0.398 gMeOH h−1·gcat −1) at 270 °C, while the one with the indium content of 8.0 wt% yielded an increased methanol selectivity by 1.8 times at 250 °C, compared with undoped one. Combining the structural characterizations with catalytic results, it was found that surface medium-strength and strong basic sites together with the contribution from interfacial defective oxygen vacancies and Cu+ sites played key promotional roles on the synthesis of methanol. This finding enables us to design new high-performance Cu-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation by finely turning their surface-interface structures.
coredata.dc:title: Tuning surface-interface structures of ZrO2 supported copper catalysts by in situ introduction of indium to promote CO2 hydrogenation to methanol
